title: Posters expose high risk ‘registered sex offender’ living in community on parole
text:
An archaic law in Tasmania is preventing "Alicia" speaking out about her violent sexual assault, as the perpetrator is close to walking free.

Posters plastered throughout a Sydney neighbourhood have led to police issuing a warning about members of the public exposing criminals in their local areas.

The printed posters, which gave out detailed information about a high risk sex offender who was reportedly living in the local area after being released with strict parole conditions into the community, were also shared to social media.

The posters shared details about the man, including his criminal history, and his current address. They said he has been living in an inner west community of Sydney, after being released on parole last year, with a strict ongoing monitoring period of three years.

His details are currently being shared to social media after the posters were found being “shared locally” in the Sydney community.

The posters included highly detailed information about the male offender, and urged members of the public to read further material about him. He has previously been found guilty of a string of violent crimes, including two different serious sexual offences, for which he has served time in prison. Since being released, he has once been convicted for breaching his parole.

The man was recommended parole with strict conditions, including monitoring by an ankle bracelet, imposed on him for a period of years, beginning in 2018.

The posters exposed the offender’s new address, and recommended a series of articles which detailed his crimes.

The man has been linked to burglaries and two violent rapes in the 1990s. Now aged in his fifties, he has a criminal record which dates back to his teenage years.

News.com.au understands that putting up the posters is not an offence, but anything that might incite violence against an individual is considered illegal.

Similar posters, targeting a different individual, were recently put up in another area in Sydney’s south.

A spokesperson for NSW Police told news.com.au they are aware of the posters and urged members of the public not to take the law into their own hands.

“Police are aware of reports of flyers circulating in the inner west area,” a spokesperson for NSW Police said in a statement.

“We would encourage the community not to attempt to take the law into their own hands, as you may be committing an offence.

“Officers from Inner West Police Area Command are conducting inquiries.”

There is currently no public register of sex offenders deemed “high risk” in Australia.

Peter Dutton proposed the establishment of a National Public Register of Child Sex Offenders — making certain key information about known offenders publicly available — in January of this year.

The goal of the public register is to improve national protections for children. There is no suggestion the man targeted in the posters was a paedophile or had committed crimes involving minors.

“It would have a strong deterrent effect on offenders and ensure that parents are not in the dark about whether a registered sex offender has access to their children,” Mr Dutton said at the start of the year.

“The abuse and exploitation of children is a global epidemic that is becoming more prevalent, more organised and more extreme.

“Thwarting that exploitation is a key priority for me as Minister for Home Affairs. I have always fought for the protection of children and this is a battle that we must win.”

The proposal by Dutton concerns itself specifically with those offenders who have abused children.
description: Posters plastered throughout a Sydney neighbourhood have led to police issuing a warning about members of the public exposing criminals in their local areas.
